unnormalised: **Rental Agreements - What you need to know before you rent in Mumbai!**
normalised: **Rental Agreements - What you need to know before you rent in Mumbai!**

unnormalised: So, you're moving to Mumbai and need a place to stay? Congrats! Getting a rental agreement sorted is probably the *most* important thing after finding your flat. Trust me, it can save you a lot of headaches down the line.
normalised: So, you're moving to Mumbai and need a place to stay? Congrats! Getting a rental agreement sorted is probably the *most* important thing after finding your flat. Trust me, it can save you a lot of headaches down the line.

unnormalised: Think of it like this: a rental agreement is your legal "vachan" or promise with your landlord, Mr. Sharma. It outlines everything – rent amount (Rs. 25,000/month, for example), security deposit (usually 2-3 months’ rent!), maintenance charges, the lock-in period (maybe 11 months initially), and even rules about pets (my cousin Priya had a *nightmare* about that!).
normalised: Think of it like this: a rental agreement is your legal "vachan" or promise with your landlord, Mister Sharma. It outlines everything – rent amount (rupees twenty five thousand per month, for example), security deposit (usually two to three months’ rent!), maintenance charges, the lock-in period (maybe eleven months initially), and even rules about pets (my cousin Priya had a *nightmare* about that!).

unnormalised: Don't just sign whatever is put in front of you. Read every clause carefully! Understand what happens if you need to break the agreement early, what the escalation clause is (how much rent increases each year, usually around 5%), and who’s responsible for repairs (like if the geyser in your bathroom gives up the ghost in the middle of winter!).
normalised: Don't just sign whatever is put in front of you. Read every clause carefully! Understand what happens if you need to break the agreement early, what the escalation clause is (how much rent increases each year, usually around five percent), and who’s responsible for repairs (like if the geyser in your bathroom gives up the ghost in the middle of winter!).

unnormalised: Things to always check: Is the agreement registered? In Maharashtra, registration is a MUST, especially for tenancies longer than 11 months. And always get a receipt for your security deposit, preferably on official letterhead. This will help you when you need to claim it back at the end of your tenancy.
normalised: Things to always check: Is the agreement registered? In Maharashtra, registration is a M U S T, especially for tenancies longer than eleven months. And always get a receipt for your security deposit, preferably on official letterhead. This will help you when you need to claim it back at the end of your tenancy.

unnormalised: It's also a good idea to clearly mention the total area of the property (e.g., 600 sq ft) and the exact address, including building name and floor number. Dr. Patil, my lawyer friend, always says clarity is key! Also, if there are any specific fittings/fixtures (like AC units or furniture), mention their condition in the agreement to avoid disputes later.

Also, if there are any specific fittings or fixtures (like A C units or furniture), mention their condition in the agreement to avoid disputes later.

unnormalised: Finally, negotiate if you can! Sometimes you can bring the rent down a bit, especially if the place has been vacant for a while. Good luck finding your perfect Mumbai flat!
